entry.title: Tracery Twitter Bots Tutorial
entry.content:
This tutorial teaches the basics of making generative Twitter bots using Tracery and Cheap Bots Done Quick. Originally presented at Lake Forest College Computer Science Club in 2019. [No Coding Experience Required!]

What are Twitter bots?

Bots on Twitter range from very simple to very complex. They can generate stories, poems, pieces of art, jokes, and more. If you want to learn more about the many types of bots out there, a good resource is Botwiki, which collects examples of bots along with tutorials, essays, and other resources. For this tutorial, we’ll focus on bots made with Tracery, a generative tool that’s easy for beginners to pick up. Here are a few examples of bots I’ve made with Tracery:

  • @unicode_faces - a bot that makes faces using Unicode characters
  • @XFilesPlotBot - a bot that comes up with new X Files plots
  • @cs_club_img_bot - a bot that tweets captioned images of my family’s cat

Tools

  • Tracery
  • Cheap Bots Done Quick (CBDQ)

You don’t have to install anything for this tutorial. It can all be done online!

Tracery Overview

Tracery is a tool built for doing basic text generation, MadLibs-style, from a list of lists that you create. (If you’re familiar with JSON, that’s what this is, but you don’t need to know what JSON is to use Tracery.) When you paste your Tracery code into Cheap Bots Done Quick and connect a Twitter account, CBDQ will automatically start generating tweets from your Tracery lists and posting them to Twitter on a schedule that you set. You can make your Tracery code as complex as you like, so there’s a lot of room to be creative.

The online Tracery editor has a helpful visualization tool for keeping track of the parts of your list and how they work together, so I recommend writing your code there rather than in another text editor. Alternately, you can use this alternate editor, which may be slightly easier to understand for beginners.

Tracery Syntax

Start by coming up with a sentence structure that can be varied with different words (think MadLibs!) and then identify the different word types you’ll need to construct that sentence. For this tutorial, I’ll generate some mystery story plot concepts. My basic sentence structure will be:

This structure could generate sentences such as ‘A little old lady investigates a murder in a quiet English village.’ or ‘A no-nonsense sheriff investigates a theft in a Western saloon.’ We’ll need to make lists of words to choose from for each of the fill-in-the-blank spots in the original sentence structure. Our lists for this example might be:

In Tracery, you put the name of the list in quotation marks, followed by a colon, and then put the list items in a set of brackets, with each item within quotation marks. When you want to randomly pick an item from another list, use this notation: #list_name#. Each list should be on a separate line, and should be followed by a comma (except the last one). The first list is your main structure, and it should be named ‘origin’. Take a look at the example code below to see this structure in action.

Example output:

Important note: Tracery is very picky about commas and new lines. If the output isn’t showing up correctly in the editor, go through and triple check that you have a comma after every list except the last one, that each list is on a new line, and that all your quotation marks are in the right places. Writing your code directly in the online Tracery editor helps with this, since the output on the right will update as you type so that you can catch errors as you go.

You also may have issues when copying and pasting code from other websites. If so, the issue can often be resolved by typing the code out by hand into the editor.

Saving Variables

At this point we’ve covered everything you need to make a very basic bot. But we can add a little more sophistication by saving variables for use later in the sentence, rather than selecting every word randomly. To store a variable, use this notation: [variableName:#variableListName#] at the beginning of the ‘origin’ list. This will not show up in the output, but it will randomly pick an item from variableListName and save it to variableName. Then, when you want to refer to that variable, use #variableName#.

Modifiers

You may want to modify certain variables by capitalizing them, putting ‘a’ or ‘an’ in front of them, or making them plural or past tense. You can do that by adding modifiers to the variables; for example, #name.capitalize# will pick a random item from the ‘name’ list and capitalize the first letter. You can also create your own modifiers if you know Javascript, but that’s beyond the scope of this tutorial. Here are some built-in modifiers:

  • #variable.capitalize# capitalizes the first letter of variable
  • #variable.capitalizeAll# capitalizes all letters of variable
  • #variable.a# adds an ‘a’ or ‘an’ in front of variable
  • #variable.s# makes variable plural
  • #variable.ed# makes variable past tense

Note: Some of the modifiers may not work properly with words that have irregular froms of the past tense/plural/etc, or if you are creating a bot in a language other than English.

Varying Structure

You may want your bot to tweet several variations on your subject. For instance, in addition to ‘A [detective] named [name] investigates a [crime] in [location]. [name] must solve the case before [event]!’, you might include a structure like ‘When a [crime] occurs in [location], #name# doesn’t want to take the case. But things get personal when #event#.’ We can do that by creating a list of structures for our bot to pick from, the same way we did with lists of words. Think of it as a MadLib with other MadLibs nested inside it.

This will choose one of the sentence formats randomly, and populates words randomly from the lists.

Hosting Your Bot

At this point, you’ve learned everything necessary to make a text bot using Tracery. You can add more and more lists with more and more items to create fairly complex bots, using just the techniques in this post. When you’re ready to put your bot onto Twitter, you can move on to this step. (Note: you can also edit your code later, after uploading it to CBDQ.)

First, create a Twitter account for your bot to tweet from. Then go to Cheap Bots Done Quick and log in with that same Twitter account. Copy and paste your Tracery code into the box that says Tracery JSON, and set how often you’d like your bot to tweet. Click save. Congratulations! You’ve made a Twitter bot!

If you’re interested in looking into making Twitter bots that go beyond what Tracery can do, I recommend visiting Botwiki for a masterlist of bot resources and tutorials.

entry.title: Piet Tutorial
entry.content:
Hi all! Today we’ll be looking at an esoteric programming language called Piet. Esoteric programming languages are languages where the concept or aesthetic of the language is usually more important than the actual functionality or usability (some examples of esoteric languages that we’ve done past CS Club tutorials on are LOLCODE and Brainfuck). No programming experience is required for this tutorial, although it will be easier if you have an understanding of how a stack works.

Piet is pretty unique in that the program is an image. Literally, you write code by placing pixels of color on a canvas. It’s inspired by the works of Piet Mondrian, who was famous for his paintings involving blocks of bright color. Today we’ll be learning the basics of Piet!

Resources:

1) A good intro to the language written by its creator; it explains how the syntax works and has links to some examples

2) An online editor for Piet

3) An ASCII table to help you print out characters

Let’s start out by making our first program! Because of the way Piet works, there’s a lot of different ways to implement any given program (you can see some different examples of fancy Hello World programs in the first link above). I’ll show a very simple example program, but see if you can create your own variations!

Before we start, you’ll need to be familiar with what a stack is. If you aren’t familiar with this term, think about a stack of books on a table; you can put more books on the top, and take books off the top, but you can’t access books in the middle of the stack. That’s how a stack works in computer programming, too. We “push” things onto the top of the stack, and “pop” them off when we want to use them, but we’re always accessing the item at the top of the stack.

I started by listing out the instructions I wanted to perform. Let’s say I want to print “Hi”. These are the ASCII values I want to print out: 72 105 (you can find these values in the ASCII table linked above). So I need to write a series of instructions that will get me those numbers and then print them out as characters (again, there’s more than one way to do this). To start, I’ll write this in pseudocode, not an actual Piet program. Here’s what I came up with:

Now we need to translate those instructions into pixels (or codels, as Piet calls them). The integers are represented by the number of codels in a particular block of color, and the commands are represented by changes of color. Read the first link above for a detailed explanation and list of commands.

You can see my program in the above image. Try running it for yourself! There are some codels that I just filled in more or less randomly, since they weren’t needed for the program.) See if you can understand how it works, and then try to make a full Hello World program on your own. Make sure to test your program frequently; it’s easy to get mixed up with this language. If you’re having trouble figuring out how the program flows from one codel to the next, start out by making a program that just goes from left to right. If you want more of a challenge, try designing a program that actually forms a picture of something!

That’s all for today! Have fun experimenting with Piet!
entry.summary: This tutorial will get you started programming with Piet, an esoteric and visually striking programming language.
